abstract.text: The phenomenon of CP violation is crucial to understand the asymmetry between matter and antimatter that exists in the Universe.

Dramatic experimental progress has been made, in particular in measurements of the behaviour of particles containing the b quark, where CP violation effects are predicted by the Kobayashi-Maskawa mechanism that is embedded in the Standard Model.
The status of these measurements and future prospects for an understanding of CP violation beyond the Standard Model are reviewed.

body_text.text: Introduction
Among the possible discrete symmetries of nature, the combined symmetry under charge conjugation (C) and parity (P ) is particularly interesting.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The C operation conjugates all internal quantum numbers, and therefore transforms particles into antiparticles and vice versa, while under P all spatial co-ordinates are inverted.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Violation of CP symmetry allows an absolute distinction between matter and antimatter to be made [1,2], and is a prerequisite for the evolution of a matter dominated universe [3].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The observation of the long-lived neutral kaon decaying to two charged pions provided the first experimental observation of CP violation [4].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Among the various ideas put forward to explain these phenomena, only that proposed by Kobayashi and Maskawa [5] has survived the test of time, and is now an integral part of the Standard Model (SM).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: By extending the quark mixing concept of Cabibbo [6] to include three quark pairs (or "families"), a single irreducible phase appears and gives rise to CP violation.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The phase of the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa (CKM) matrix is the sole source of CP violation in the Standard Model.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Therefore, all possible CP violating observables in the quark sector are related to this single quantity, which allows for a wide range of tests of the SM predictions to be made.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Remarkably, the theory has survived all such tests to date.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In particular, there are a wide range of observables in the B sector, i.e. with particles involving b quarks, that are useful to test the SM predictions for CP violation.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: It is the purpose of this review to describe these observables, giving both the current experimental status as well as future prospects.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: It is a striking feature of CP violation in the B sector that many of the experimental measurements can be interpreted without the need for detailed calculation of hadronic effects in the initial and final states.

body_text.text: Features of B physics experiments at e + e − colliders
A great deal of B physics has been achieved by the asymmetric e + e − collider experiments BaBar [56,57] and Belle [58], located at the SLAC and KEK collider facilities, respectively.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at e + e − colliders

body_text.text: They share, and their physics reach is defined by, the following characteristics:
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at e + e − colliders

body_text.text: • The production of B meson/antimeson pairs via the decay of a bb resonance produced in the e + e − collision.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at e + e − colliders

body_text.text: When the collision energy corresponds to the mass of the Υ(4S) resonance, the only species produced are the B + and B 0 (anti)mesons.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at e + e − colliders

body_text.text: The production is coherent, so that the wavefunction of the produced B 0 and B 0 pair evolves in phase until one or the other decays.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at e + e − colliders

body_text.text: By operating at the Υ(5S) resonance it is, however, possible to produce also B 0 s -B 0 s pairs.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at e + e − colliders

body_text.text: • Asymmetric e + e − beam energies which provide a boost large enough to resolve B 0 , but not B 0 s , oscillations.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at e + e − colliders

body_text.text: As the centre-of-mass energy of each collision is known, it can be used to distinguish genuine B hadrons, each carrying half of the centre-of-mass energy, from backgrounds.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at e + e − colliders

body_text.text: • Detectors with close to 4π solid angle coverage, providing the ability to efficiently reconstruct all visible decay products of the produced B particles, both charged and neutral.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at e + e − colliders

body_text.text: Solenoidal magnetic fields allow track momenta to be determined; the field strength (1.5 T for both BaBar and Belle) is optimised to provide good resolution while allowing all but the lowest momentum tracks to escape the inner detector.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at e + e − colliders

body_text.text: Particle identification devices [59,60] provide the capability to distinguish efficiently between all the different species of stable charged particles over the momentum range of interest.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at e + e − colliders

body_text.text: • Trigger systems that are highly efficient for BB events, allowing essentially all such events to be saved to tape without any inefficiencies.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at e + e − colliders

body_text.text: Because of the clean production environment and hermetic detectors, e + e − collider experiments are particularly useful for studying CP violating decays involving one or more neutral particles in the final state.

body_text.text: Features of B physics experiments at hadron colliders

The most significant hadron collider experiments to date, in terms of B physics and CP violation, are D0 and CDF at the Tevatron proton-antiproton collider, as well as CMS, ATLAS and LHCb at the LHC proton-proton collider.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at hadron colliders

body_text.text: Although there are some important differences in the production environment between these two colliders, the experiments largely share the following characteristics:
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at hadron colliders

body_text.text: • The production of B (anti)hadrons via gluon fusion (LHC) or qq annihilation (Tevatron), which gives access to all species of B (anti)hadrons.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at hadron colliders

body_text.text: The production is incoherent, so that any combination of beauty hadron and antihadron can in principle be produced together.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at hadron colliders

body_text.text: • A geometrical acceptance that is far from hermetic.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at hadron colliders

body_text.text: Although D0, CDF, CMS and ATLAS all cover close to 4π of solid angle (and are therefore equipped with solenoidal magnets), the production of bb pairs in high energy hadron collisions is predominantly at large pseudorapidity, i.e. close to the beam-line, so that many of the decay products pass through the uninstrumented region.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at hadron colliders

body_text.text: The LHCb detector is designed as a forward spectrometer, covering the approximate pseudorapidity region 2 < η < 5, in order to maximise the acceptance for B physics.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at hadron colliders

body_text.text: A dipole magnet, with bending power of about 4 T m, deflects charged particles and allows their momentum to be determined.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at hadron colliders

body_text.text: • A sufficiently large boost of the produced (anti)hadrons to enable, together with precision vertex detectors, both B 0 and B 0 s oscillations to be resolved.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at hadron colliders

body_text.text: • Large numbers of additional particles from the underlying proton-(anti)proton interaction which make it infeasible to perform the same kind of full event reconstruction as at e + e − colliders.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at hadron colliders

body_text.text: • Very high production cross-sections, that necessitate the separation of bb events from other types of events using non-trivial trigger systems.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at hadron colliders

body_text.text: The trigger systems introduce substantial inefficiencies for certain B (anti)hadron decay channels.
body_text.section: Features of B physics experiments at hadron colliders

body_text.text: • Multiple inelastic collisions per beam crossing, known as "pile-up".

The wealth of experimental results on CP violation in the B system, primarily from the BaBar, Belle and LHCb experiments, have transformed the understanding in this sector.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: The Kobayashi-Maskawa mechanism, that provides a unique source of CP violation within the SM, has been confirmed.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: Moreover, the consistency of measurements with SM predictions leads to increasingly strong constraints on effects beyond the SM.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: This remarkable progress has been achieved due to the development of new techniques in both experimental and theoretical methods.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: Since the currently achieved precision is far from the level at which these approaches are expected to reach fundamental limitations, significant further progress can be anticipated.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: A next generation of experiments is planned, and there are exciting prospects for significant advances in this sector in the next ten years.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: Some of these, such as the observation of CP violation in b baryon decays, and of CP violation in mixing/decay interference in the B 0 s system, are anticipated within the SM.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: For some others it remains to be seen whether or not the effects seen in the data can be explained by SM dynamics alone: these include the Kπ puzzle and the large asymmetries seen in regions of phase space of charmless three-body B decays.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: There are also observables where any observation of CP violation at the achievable precision would be a clear signal of beyond SM physics: examples include the parameters of CP violation in both B 0 and B 0 s mixing, or in decays to final states involving photons or leptons.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: The powerful approach of testing the consistency of the SM paradigm through global fits to CKM matrix parameters requires improved measurements of several important quantities including γ, β and β s .
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: The study of CP violation in the B sector will therefore remain a high-priority component of the global programme in particle physics for the foreseeable future.
body_text.section: Summary

body_text.text: Complemented by progress in other areas, including kaon and charm physics, precision measurements of low energy observables, searches for new phenomena at the energy frontier, and neutrino physics, there is a real possibility of a breakthrough.
body_text.section: Summary
